articles.description: Added: testing and CI/CD workflows
articles.title: v1.10.2

articles.description:
Added: experimental support for iTunes podcast feed: Demo | Source. With this new release, you can render an audio control to play the mp3 file and display iTunes episode duration. It is "experimental" due to these caveats:

This feature is currently only available through custom template.
iTunes has no strict format requirement for duration. The unit is most likely seconds but can be "hh:mm:ss" or "mm:ss" for some sources. A future version may expose a human readable string to the template.
No image support yet. Some shows might have disabled CORS or use a relative URL for image, which forces osmosfeed to download the image during build. A future version may support it.
You can't republish the podcast in the feed output. Supporting this goes beyond the scope of the project at the moment.
Fixed: the articles in template data were not sorted.
Thank you @Zenigata
articles.title: v1.9.0

articles.description: Fixed: UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Error: At least one option must be a string
articles.title: v1.8.1

articles.description:
Changed: Smart summary truncation. When there is no dedicated summary (only Atom feed has it, and many sites don't use it) from the source, we check if the content/description (Both Atom and RSS) field is long enough to be full text. If so, it will be truncated into a "pseudo" summary. If not, we assume the source used the content field as summary, and it will be displayed in full length.
Thank you: @LooperXX.
articles.title: v1.8.0

articles.author: Kevin Powell
articles.description:
As awesome as flexbox is, what it’s doing under the hood is actually a little strange because, by default, it is doing two things at once. It first looks at the content size which is what we would get if by declaring width: max-content on an element. But on top of that, flex-shrink is also doing some work allowing the items to be smaller, but only if needed.
Let’s break those two down and see how they work together.
The post Equal Columns With Flexbox: It’s More Complicated Than You Might Think appeared first on CSS-Tricks.
You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Equal Columns With Flexbox: It’s More Complicated Than You Might Think

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nic Chan)
articles.description: In a new short series of posts, we highlight some of the useful tools and techniques for developers and designers. Recently we’ve covered HTML Emails and SVG Generators. This time we look into different kinds of tools to help you streamline your accessibility testing process. Don’t miss the next one.
articles.title: A Complete Guide To Accessibility Tooling

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: When developing themes and plugins for WordPress, we need to test them in different environments. How can we create multiple testing sites on our computer, quickly and easily, without having to become a sysadmin?
articles.title: Spinning Up Multiple WordPress Sites Locally With DevKinsta

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast, we’re talking about image optimization. What steps should we follow for performant images in 2021? We talk to expert Addy Osmani to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 39 With Addy Osmani: Image Optimization

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stephanie Eckles)
articles.description: Spoiler alert: tooltips, modals, tabs, carousels, and dropdown menus are some of the user interface components that require more than CSS. To ensure accessibility of your interface, JavaScript is a necessary addition to accomplish focus management, respond to keyboard events, and toggle ARIA attributes.
articles.title: When CSS Isn’t Enough: JavaScript Requirements For Accessible Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: Design often revolves around visuals, but the other senses deserve love too. In this article, we tune in to audio features that are making sites sing.
articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Making Use Of Audio

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: We don’t need to write everything from scratch every single time. With boilerplates and starter kits, we can set up our projects faster, and get to work immediately.
articles.title: Useful Front-End Boilerplates And Starter Kits

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stefan Judis)
articles.description: Building a faster website can be a rocket task these days. There are so many things to consider, so it’s challenging to get everything right. Here are some less-known tools that might help you get there.
articles.title: Three Front-End Auditing Tools I Discovered Recently

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: What makes relational selector one of the most requested features and how are we, as developers, working around not having it? In this article, we’re going to check the early spec of the :has selector, and see how it should improve the CSS workflow once it’s released.
articles.title: Meet :has, A Native CSS Parent Selector (And More)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: It’s here! For the last year, we’ve been working with Addy Osmani on a new Smashing Book all around image optimization. And now it’s here. Meet “Image Optimization”, our deep-dive guide to understand how to deliver high-quality images on the web fast.
articles.title: From AVIF to WebP: A New Smashing Book By Addy Osmani

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Prince Chukwudire)
articles.description: In this guide, we’ll be taking a general look at the concepts of forward geocoding and reverse geocoding, and will build a mini-app that applies these concepts to display specific locations, using Mapbox and Vue.js 2.6.11 to achieve this.
articles.title: How To Build A Geocoding App In Vue.js Using Mapbox

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nwani Victory)
articles.description: Modern browsers provide good support for JavaScript modules, but module bundlers such as webpack stay a critical part of the JavaScript toolchain. Let’s take a deep dive into what webpack is and how to use it in your development workflow.
articles.title: Getting Started With Webpack

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Shawn Wildermuth)
articles.description: Writing large-scale Vue applications can be a challenge. In this article, Shawn Wildermuth dives into the pros and cons of approaches like factories, shared objects, and using Vuex. He also explains what is coming in Vuex 5.0 that might change how we all use shared state in Vue 3.
articles.title: Managing Shared State In Vue 3

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Barry Pollard)
articles.description: Google’s Core Web Vitals initiative has taken the SEO and Web Performance worlds by storm and many sites are busy optimizing their Page Experience to maximize the ranking factor. The Cumulative Layout Shift metric is causing trouble to a lot of sites, so let’s have a look at ways of addressing any issues for that metric.
articles.title: How To Fix Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) Issues

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jennifer Brehm)
articles.description: Getting a good performance score from Google is hard for any website — but doing so for an online store is even harder. We achieved green scores — even several for mobile. Here is how we did it.
articles.title: Improving The Performance Of An Online Store (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we’re talking about React performance. What factors slow our React apps down, and how can we fix it? Drew McLellan talks to expert Ivan Akulov to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 38 With Ivan Akulov: Why Is My React App Slow?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: Amazon allows visitors to display prices in their own currency. Thanks to *ExchangeRatesApi.io*, we can do the same for our online shops, providing a better experience to our customers. Let’s find out how.
articles.title: Setting Up A Currency Convertor With ExchangeRatesApi.io

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: What could be a better way to welcome June than with some colorful inspiration? Well, we might have something for you: wallpapers created with love by artists and designers from across the globe.
articles.title: Happy June Vibes For Your Screen (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Shalabh Vyas)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll be re-using the foundational WYSIWYG Editor built in the first article to build a commenting system for a WYSIWYG Editor that enables users to select text inside a document and share their comments on it. Let’s dig in!
articles.title: Adding A Commenting System To A WYSIWYG Editor

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Meet useful Visual Studio Code extensions for web developers: little helpers to minimize slow-downs and frustrations, and boost developer’s workflow along the way. With auto log messages, auto code formatting, file utils, file labels, code snippets, highlight brackets, tags, indents and workspaces, onboarding and remote SSH.
articles.title: Useful VS Code Extensions For Front-End Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Miroslav Bekyarov)
articles.description: While web builders have been around for a long time, it wasn’t until recently that they became practical for professional use. Closing the gap between design and code has become the north star for many companies and we are seeing a wave of tools that deliver on this promise.
articles.title: How To Build And Launch Powerful Responsive Websites With Editor X

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Carie Fisher)
articles.description: Discover which SVG patterns we should avoid and which patterns are the most inclusive when comparing different combinations of OSs, browsers, and screen readers.
articles.title: Accessible SVGs: Perfect Patterns For Screen Reader Users

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Tobias Günther)
articles.description: Mistakes. These cruel villains do not even stop at the beautiful world of software development. But although we cannot avoid making mistakes, we can learn to undo them! This post will show the right tools for your daily work with Git.
articles.title: A Guide To Undoing Mistakes With Git (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Barry Pollard)
articles.description: Web fonts are often terrible for web performance and none of the font loading strategies are particularly effective to address that. Upcoming font options may finally deliver on the promise of making it easier to align fallback fonts to the final fonts.
articles.title: A New Way To Reduce Font Loading Impact: CSS Font Descriptors

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: CSS Container queries bring media queries closer to the target elements themselves and enables them to adapt to virtually any given container or layout. In this article, we’re going to cover CSS container query basics and how to use them today with progressive enhancement or polyfills.
articles.title: CSS Container Queries: Use-Cases And Migration Strategies

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Shalabh Vyas)
articles.description: Let’s build a rich text, WYSIWYG-editor that supports rich text, images, links and some nuanced features from word processing apps. We will use SlateJS to build the shell of the editor and then add a toolbar and custom configurations.
articles.title: Building A Rich Text Editor (WYSIWYG)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lješnjanin)
articles.description: Front-end and design are remarkably complex these days. That’s why we invite kind, smart folks from the community to run online workshops for all of us to learn together. And we have new ones coming up, and we’d like to kindly welcome you to join in.
articles.title: Boost Your Skills Online: Smashing Workshops On Front-End And Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: A step-by-step tutorial on adding authentication and authorization to your Next.js apps, with Auth0. We’ll be using a Next.js SDK to connect our application to the Auth0 API and will create the dynamic API route for React.
articles.title: How To Implement Authentication In Next.js With Auth0

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Everything to keep in mind when designing and building a mega-dropdown, common pitfalls, hover entry/exit delays, trajectory triangle technique and SVG path exit areas.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Mega-Dropdown Hover Menus

articles.description: Bookmarklets are browser bookmarks that execute JavaScript instead of opening a webpage. They're also known as bookmark applets, favlets, or JavaScript bookmarks. Bookmarklets are natively available in all major browsers, including Mozilla Firefox and Chromium-based browsers like Chrome or Brave. Scripting with JavaScriptLearning how to write scripts provides many benefits,
articles.title: What are Bookmarklets and How to Make Them

articles.title: JavaScript Split – How to Split a String into an Array in JS

articles.description: In this article, I'll explain two important concepts in statistics: skewness and kurtosis. articles.title: Skewness and Kurtosis – Positively Skewed and Negatively Skewed Distributions in Statistics Explained

Learn all about DevOps in this comprehensive course for beginners with three technical tutorials. Colin Chartier created this course. He is the co-founder and CEO at LayerCI.

articles.description: To understand what this truly means in JavaScript, let's take a look at a very similar concept in the English Language: Polysemy. Let's consider the word "run". Run is a single word which could mean many different things depending on the context. “I will run home” – means to move quickly

articles.description: As a freelance developer, knowing how much to charge for a project can often feel like a gamble. It's easy to wonder "Am I setting my price too high?" This is normally the first question that comes to mind. And your brain will probably meet this question with a resounding
articles.title: What to Charge as a Freelance Developer – and Why You Should Avoid Being the Cheapest

articles.description: Python decorators allow you to change the behavior of a function without modifying the function itself. In this article I will show you how to create and use decorators. You will see how easy it is to use this advanced Python feature. In this article I will discuss the following

articles.description: Any sufficiently old codebase eventually starts to contain legacy code. Architecture, performance, comments, and more begin to degrade the moment after they are written. Some parts of the codebase last longer than other parts, but inevitably new coding standards emerge to reduce technical debt. Then you have to rework a
